sub_title: Senior System Design Engineer: electron cameras and X-ray detectors at Thermo Fisher Scientific
summary:
Education: high energy physics background (Nuclear, Particle, Astrophysics, and Cosmology) with a double PhD in X-ray and Gamma-ray imaging (keV, MeV, GeV).

Working experience:  X-ray (>1 keV), Gamma-ray (0.5 MeV - 100 MeV) imaging and electron microscopy  with a specialization in X-ray/Gamma-ray/electron Imaging, Image acquisition, and detectors:

working experience with X-Rays and Gamma-Ray Imaging:
■ Imaging Techniques: Compton imaging, coded aperture imaging, pair conversion imaging, focusing Laue lenses, spectral computed tomography (CT), X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRD), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, and spectral powder diffraction.

■ Detectors and Cameras:
(simulations and modeling): modeling, simulation, characterization and optimization for Compton Imaging (energy resolution, spatial resolution, angular resolution, and polarimetry) 

(Detector development): measuring performance parameters (dark current, inter-strip capacitance, bulk capacitance), developing detector readout test bench (detector +  ASIC + FPGA + PC link ), detector prototypes, alphas and betas.

(Image processing): to read raw data from prototypes, to achieve super-resolution (Timepix3 detectors), to improve the signal-to-noise ratio (suppressing intrinsic XRF emission from the detector), to measure image thermal and mechanical drifts.

(X-ray based experiments) using laboratory X-ray tube sources synchrotron sources, radioactive isotopes, motorized stages (source, sample, detector), clean room, 

■ Supervision of Bachelor and Master laboratory work and Master internships.

■ Applications: National and international R&D projects in collaboration with academic and industrial partners for Astrophysics applications (keV-MeV-GeV Astronomy), security applications (next-generation airport luggage scanners), and Electron microscopy (energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) ) 


working experience with electron microscopy:
■ Imaging Techniques: Transmission Electron Microscopy, Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy, Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy.

■ Detectors and Cameras: Electron cameras and detectors prototypes testing and performance evaluation for Transmission Electron Microscopy and for Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy.

■ Thermofisher FEI electron microscopes.

■ Market: Materials Science, Semiconductors, Life Science, Oil and Gas

IN SOFTWARE:
■ C++, Python, Megalib (Geant4), Matlab, Silvaco and IDL for data analysis and modeling/simulation

profile_positions.description:
R&D senior system engineer: X-ray detectors and electron cameras for Electron Microscopy :

Electron cameras for Imaging (direct and indirect detectors and cameras, CCD and CMOS):

X-ray detectors for Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy:
- Image thermal/optical/mechanical drift analysis (python, ImageJ)
- Spectral performance validation
- Software functionality validation
- Detector integration
- python scripting for test automation


- Support for international partners on testing camera prototypes
- FEI electron microscopes
profile_positions.title: Senior System Engineer Image, Acquisition and Detectors

profile_positions.description:
Postdoctoral Scholar in DTU Department of Physics: X-ray Energy dispersive detectors specialist (keV-MeV photon range) and experimental physicist on X-ray Tomography and diffraction

I worked on X-ray Tomography (12-160 keV): CIL project (Checked in Luggage) And Enhanced Airport Security and information (EASi project):

• Objective: Build the next generation airport Checked in/hand-luggage scanners.

• I acquired x-ray tomography measurements for hundreds of non-threats, liquid-threats, solid-threats and compound-threats to build a reference library.

• I acquired x-ray tomography data for compound materials to simulate luggage contents.

• Detector Technology: Multix ME100 energy dispersive line detectors (3mm CdTe crystals).

I worked on Powder Diffraction experiments for a confidential project

I worked as a detector physicist to optimize the performance of detectors:

- Experiments to achieve sub-pixel resolution in 2D Si/CdTe Hybrid Pixel Detectors (Timepix and Timepix3 ASIC technology), Physical Pixel Pitch = 55 μm.

- Corrected the intrinsic XRF signal in a CdTe Timepix3 detector.

- Experiments/supervision of students to lower the temperature of Timepix3 CdTe detectors to improve energy resolution (supervised a Master2 Thesis project).

- Regular Time Over Threshold Energy measurements and Calibration, Timepix and Timepix3 ASIC configuration.

- Study, compare and report on the status of state of the art x-ray semiconductor detector solutions worldwide.

- Detector efficiency simulations.

- Synchrotron Beam time experience.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
PhD Researcher on modelling and characterizing  X-ray  energy dispersive detectors for Astrophysics applications:

I worked on PACT (0.1-100 MeV) which is an R&D project to develop a Pair and Compton space-borne Telescope. It utilizes the Compton imaging technique (up to10 MeV) and the Pair conversion imaging technique (10-100 MeV)

•	I used C++  and SILVACO to characterize and model the main detector for PACT (silicon double sided strip detectors): Depletion voltage, Capacitances, Leakage currents, Electric field profile, electron/hole motilities…. Using this information I simulated the energy resolution of the detector.

•	I performed Monte-Carlo simulations using MEGALIB and C++ to model the telescope and simulate its sensitivities, energy and angular resolution.

•	I used an RLC meter to measure the depletion voltage and the capacitance of silicon DSSDs and compared with simulations.

•	I installed and tested the PACT DSSD readout chain (DSSD + ASIC + FPGA).
ASTROGAM (0.3 MeV-few GeV) is a future Pair and Compton Telescope similar to PACT but extends the operational range into GeV energies.

•	I used SILVACO to simulate the performance of silicon DSSDs for the telescope’s proposal to the European Space Agency call for medium sized mission.


I worked on WPOL (2-200 keV) which is a future Polarization measurement telescope based on the coded mask technology. It is formed of a coded mask on top of a two-layer Compton imager.

•	I used MEGALIB to model the Coded Mask and the silicon detection layer.

•	I used MEGALIB to perform MonteCarlo simulations to optimize WPOL’s detection efficiency and simulate its minimum detectable polarization at 100 keV.
profile_positions.title: PhD Researcher

profile_positions.description:
PhD Researcher on modelling and characterizing X-ray energy dispersive detectors for Astrophysics applications: 

I worked on the LAUE (100-700 keV) project which is an R&D X-ray focusing space-borne telescope based on Bragg’s diffraction. It is formed of a large focusing lens and a focal plane multilayered Compton detector:

•	I used MEGALIB to model the focusing effect of the LAUE lens and the focal plane detector.

•	I used MEGALIB to perform Monte-Carlo simulations: Photons pass through the lens and are focused (Bragg’s diffraction) on the focal plane detector where they undergo several interactions (mostly photoelectric absorption and Compton scattering).

•	I developed algorithms (C++) to analyze the above results and established a new method to  reconstruct the point spread function based on the type and the photon interaction sequence:
I presented three detector solutions (Silicon DSSDs, Germanium DSSDs or CdTe detectors)
I defined the required detector thickness to achieve optimal detection efficiency.
I defined the position resolution requirements for each detector to ensure high quality image reconstruction (reconstructed point spread function).

•	I used SILVACO to simulate the expected capacitance and depletion voltage of the selected detectors (Silicon or Germanium DSSDs).
profile_positions.title: PhD Researcher

profile_positions.description:
•	I used IDL to analyze the spectral performance of an LaBr3 scintillation crystal using radioactive sources (X-rays, Gamma rays and electrons), photo-multipliers and optical fibers to measure the energy and positions of interactions.

•      I used IDL to simulate a 2 layer Compton detector based on a Si scattering layer and an LaBr3 absorbing layer.

•	I attended a four weeks laboratory training part of a detection course during my Master 2. I worked with photomultipliers and various radioactive sources for energy calibration purposes.
